questions.question:
Question 1: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought unconscious to the emergency ward. In order to rule 
out hypothermia, how will you best measure his temperature?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the rectal temperature would be the best site to measure the core 
body temperature. At extremes of high or low temperatures, like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures 
are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperature. The infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is 
representative of the core body temperature. However, it often ends up measuring the 
temperature of the ear canal. This is because of inadequate insertion into the ear canal due to 
poor manufacturing design or the presence of cerumen. Hence, it is not a reliable method of 
measuring the core body temperature.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient in the emergency ward stays still while lying supine and hesitates to move. He also 
has very shallow breathing. This attitude of the patient is most likely due to which of the 
following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonitis. A patient with peritonitis lies supine 
without movement and has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain. Option A: In renal colic, patients have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain. Option C: In acute pancreatitis, the patient usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest 
position because of abdominal pain. Option D: Patients with meningitis present with neck stiffness.

questions.question:
Question 3: An alcohol addict presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, he is found to have 
pallor. Peripheral smear showed macrocytes and anisocytosis. Which of the following findings 
is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia likely due to folate deficiency 
caused by alcohol addiction. Folate deficiency leads to atrophic glossitis because of damage to the 
epithelial surfaces. 15 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Migratory glossitis / geographic tongue is due to rapid loss and regrowth of filiform 
papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with 
psoriasis and reactive arthritis. Option C: Strawberry tongue is due to the hypertrophy of fungiform papillae. It is seen in scarlet 
fever and Kawasaki disease. 16 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Macroglossia is an abnormal enlargement of the tongue and can be congenital or 
acquired. New-onset macroglossia in adults is highly suggestive of amyloidosis.

questions.question:
Question 4: 7 
Sold by @itachibot A woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the 
following may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.explanation:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is seen 
when the concentration of deoxygenated or reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL. Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin 0.5 gm%. Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation <85%. In dark-skinned individuals, it 
may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%. The types of cyanosis are: 17 
Sold by @itachibot Central cyanosis 
Peripheral cyanosis Due to diminished arterial ox 
ygen saturation/presence of a 
bnormal hemoglobin derivati 
ve. Due to diminished peripheral blood flow. Mucous membranes and skin Mucous membranes of the or 
al cavity or those beneath the 
tongue are spared. are both affected Decreases after O2suppleme 
ntation Does not decrease after O2su 
pplementation

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following skin findings is not associated with an endocrine abnormality?
questions.explanation:
Casal’s necklace is not associated with an endocrine abnormality. It is a feature of pellagra, which 
occurs due to the deficiency of niacin. Option A: Acanthosis nigricans is seen in multiple endocrinopathies like acromegaly, Cushing’s 
syndrome, polycystic ovary syndrome, and insulin-resistant diabetes mellitus. Option B: Diffuse hyperpigmentation is seen in Addison’s disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome. Option D: Purple striae are seen in Cushing’s disease.

questions.question: Question 6: What are petechiae?

options.a: Large extravasation of blood in the skin

questions.explanation:
Petechiae are defined as skin hemorrhages appearing as minute non-blanching spots that measure 
less than 2 mm. A few conditions causing petechiae have been stated below: • Infectious diseases: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, infective endocarditis, meningococcemia, 
and viral hemorrhagic fevers. • Non-infectious conditions: Vasculitis, thrombocytopenia, leukemia, scurvy, and vitamin K 
deficiency • Drugs: Anticoagulants (warfarin, heparin), quinine, etc. Large extravasation of blood in the skin is known as ecchymosis. Purpura are also non-blanching spots but unlike petechiae, they measure  3 mm in size.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the 
following conditions is/are associated with this lesion? 8 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi (nevus araneus). They are seen in: • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use 18 
Sold by @itachibot • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease • Thyrotoxicosis They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the 
skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the centre 
outward.

questions.question:
Question 8: You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following 
conditions is least likely to cause this finding?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely 
to cause digital clubbing. Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to 
the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface. Causes of clubbing are: • Pulmonary • Bronchogenic carcinoma • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis • Interstitial lung diseases • Cystic fibrosis • Sarcoidosis • Asbestosis • GI • Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease) • Sprue, celiac disease • Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel • Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary • Chronic active hepatitis • Cardiovascular • Cyanotic congenital heart disease • Subacute bacterial endocarditis • Aortic aneurysm • Arteriovenous fistula • Patent ductus arteriosus with right to left shunt • Atrial myxoma • Endocrine • Grave’s disease (thyroid acropachy) 19 
Sold by @itachibot • CNS • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing) • Skin disease • Palmoplantar keratoderma • Fischer-Volavsek syndrome. • Malignancies • Thyroid cancer • Thymus cancer • Hodgkin disease • Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia. Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is 
present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 40-year-old patient presents with loss of appetite, jaundice, and easy bruisability. He is a 
chronic alcohol user, and the following abnormality is noted on examination. What is the 
most likely cause of this nail change?
questions.explanation:
The nail change seen in the given image is leukonychia totalis. It is a prominent feature of 
hypoalbuminemic states. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of liver cirrhosis, which leads to 
hypoalbuminemia. Leukonychia is an opaque whitish discoloration of the nail and is seen in the following conditions: • Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency • Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine • Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiforme, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride) • Idiopathic Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed leukonychia striata or Aldrich–
Mees lines. 20 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A resident is examining a patient with bilateral leg swelling below the knees. He notes that on 
applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. What is the likely cause of the 
edema?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral non-pitting edema in the lower limbs is suggestive of myxedema. While chronic lymphangitis and acute lymphatic filariasis can also cause non-pitting edema, they 
usually have a unilateral/localized presentation. Nephrotic syndrome and heart failure cause bilateral pitting edema. Causes of generalized edema include: • Heart failure • Chronic renal failure • Nephrotic syndrome • Liver cirrhosis Causes of localized edema include: • Thrombophlebitis • Chronic lymphangitis • Resection of regional lymph nodes • Filariasis

questions.question:
Question 11: While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above 
his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse, which is not seen in left-sided 
heart failure. 21 
Sold by @itachibot Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. 
This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called 
Corrigan's pulse. The various causes of the collapsing pulse include • Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of 
increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance. • Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, 
marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva • High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's 
disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism)

questions.question: Question 12: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension:

options.a: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
options.b: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
options.c: Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
options.d: Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.explanation:
Orthostatic hypotension or postural hypotension is defined as a sustained drop in systolic BP of 
20 mmHg or diastolic BP of 10 mmHg after 3 min of standing. It can manifest as lightheadedness/dizziness, weakness or tiredness, difficulty 
thinking/concentrating, blurred vision, and anxiety. In non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension such as hypovolemia, the drop in the blood 
pressure is accompanied by a compensatory increase in heart rate of >15 beats/min. In 
neurogenic causes, there is aggravation or precipitation of orthostatic hypotension by autonomic 
stressors like a meal, hot bath, or exercise. Non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension include • Cardiac pump failure - myocardial infarction, myocarditis, aortic stenosis • Hypovolemia - dehydration, diarrhea, hemorrhage • Metabolic - adrenocortical insufficiency, pheochromocytoma • Venous pooling - sepsis, prolonged standing, or recumbency • Medications - alpha-blockers, diuretics, phenothiazines, tricyclic antidepressants Treatment includes removing reversible causes like drugs causing hypotension. 
Non-pharmacological interventions include patient education regarding staged moves from supine 
to upright, raising the head of the bed, and increasing dietary fluid and salt. If these fail, drugs 
like fludrocortisone and midodrine can be given.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 30-year-old African farmer presents with Winterbottom’s sign. This sign is due to the 
involvement of:
questions.explanation:
Winterbottom’s sign is due to the involvement of posterior cervical nodes. It is seen in African 
trypanosomiasis. African trypanosomiasis is a vector born disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei 
gambiense/rhodesiense. It is transmitted through the bite of a Tsetse fly. 22 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical syndrome includes hemolymphatic disease with associated Winterbottom's sign and a 
maculopapular rash primarily involving the trunk. At a later stage, the patient can present with 
features suggestive of meningoencephalitis.

questions.question: Question 14: Relative bradycardia occurs in:
questions.explanation:
In the given options typhoid, Q fever, and leptospirosis are infectious causes of relative 
bradycardia. Relative bradycardia, also known as Faget's sign, is observed when patients exhibit a lower heart 
rate than anticipated in relation to an increase in body temperature. Body temperature is 
commonly regarded as a factor that independently influences heart rate. It is estimated that for 
each 1°C (1.8°F) rise in temperature, the heart rate typically increases by approximately 15-20 
beats per minute. While this pulse-temperature dissociation is not highly sensitive or specific for establishing a 
diagnosis, it can still prove beneficial in resource-limited settings due to its easy accessibility and 
simplicity. Infectious causes of relative bradycardia include: • Salmonella typhi • Francisella tularensis • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever) • Leptospira interrogans • Legionella pneumophila • Rickettsia spp. • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus) • Corynebacterium diphtheriae • Plasmodium spp. (malaria) Noninfectious causes include: • Drug fever • Beta-blocker use • Central nervous system lesions • Malignant lymphoma • Factitious fever

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with rheumatic heart disease now presents with fever and the following nail finding. 
The nail lesions most likely are?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Splinter hemorrhages are 
seen in the nails of these patients. 23 
Sold by @itachibot Subungual splinter hemorrhages are classically identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail 
bed. Other peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following: • Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding • Purulent purpura • Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules usually found on the distal pads of the digits • Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles • Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers

questions.question:
Question 16: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a fever for the past 5 days. On examination, 
tender lesions were found on his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable 
diagnosis? 12 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is infective endocarditis. Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They 
usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar 
eminences. Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include: • Roth spots: These are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres. • Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles. The 
image is shown below.

questions.question: Question 17: On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicate:
questions.explanation:
On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicates a palpable murmur. Thrills are 
the palpable vibrations produced by turbulent blood flow causing murmurs. 24 
Sold by @itachibot Palpable S3 and S4 cause a double thrust in the apical impulse. Palpable right ventricular systole is known as heave which is felt in the left parasternal area.

questions.question:
Question 18: As an intern in the emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as 
correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation?

options.a: Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
options.b: Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus
options.d: Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus

questions.explanation:
The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the 
tip of the nose to the ear to the xiphisternum. The approximate length is 120-125 cm. The markings indicate the traversing of the tube through 
various parts of the GIT: • 40 cm: Cardia of the stomach • 50 cm: Body of the stomach • 60 cm: Pylorus • 70 cm: Duodenum A nasogastric tube or Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. 
The tube is then gently inserted through the nostril and advanced until it reaches 10 cm. The 
patient is encouraged to swallow, allowing the tube to move down the esophagus with successive 
swallows until it reaches the measured distance. Subjective confirmation involves insufflating air through the proximal opening of the NG tube and 
listening for the sound of air in the left upper quadrant where the stomach is located. Objective 
confirmation can be obtained through pH measurement, chest or abdominal radiographs, 
ultrasound, or calorimetric capnometry. While widely practiced, blind NG tube insertion can lead to complications such as coiling of the 
tube in the nasopharynx, incorrect placement in the bronchial passage, or even esophageal 
perforation.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient presents with excessive thirst, unexplained weight loss, visual blurring, genital 
thrush, and lethargy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is hyperglycemia. The symptoms of hyperglycemia include: • Polyuria • Polydipsia • Weight loss • Fatigue • Blurry vision • Frequent superficial infections (vaginitis, fungal skin infections) • Slow healing of skin lesions after minor trauma. 25 
Sold by @itachibot Note: The metabolic derangements occurring in these patients are due to osmotic diuresis and 
a catabolic state caused by urinary loss of glucose and increased muscle breakdown. Blurred 
vision results from changes in the water content of the lens.

questions.question: Question 20: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is
questions.explanation:
The temperature of the water bath for a patient with frostbite should be maintained between 37- 
40°C (Option A). Circulating water is preferred for treatment. In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact 
with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vasoconstriction. It usually 
affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, 
chin, and cheeks. The treatment includes - extraction from cold environment, rapid rewarming, analgesics for pain 
during thawing, antithrombotics or thrombolytics, cleaning of the injured area with soap or 
antiseptics, tetanus prophylaxis, monitoring for compartment syndrome and finally, elective late 
amputation after imaging in severe cases. 26 
Sold by @itachibot Acid-Base Disorders
